questions.text: A Chronic Alcoholic with symptoms of ataxia, CN6(Cranial Nerve 6) involvement, Nystagmus is brought to the emergency. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This condition is a neurological emergency typically caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is often seen in chronic alcoholics. The classic triad of symptoms includes:

  • Ataxia (lack of coordination)
  • Cranial nerve VI (6) involvement, leading to lateral rectus muscle weakness and resulting in diplopia(double vision)
  • Nystagmus (involuntary eye movements)
  • This triad, along with the patient's alcohol use history, strongly suggests Wernicke's encephalopathy, which requires immediate treatment with thiamine supplementation to prevent irreversible damage and progression to Korsakoff syndrome.

Incorrect Options Explanations:

  • B.Korsakoff syndrome: This is a chronic condition that follows Wernicke's encephalopathy if left untreated. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, particularly anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and confabulation (fabrication of stories to fill in memory gaps). However, Korsakoff syndrome is more associated with chronic memory deficits rather than the acute symptoms described in the scenario (ataxia, cranial nerve involvement, nystagmus).
  • C.Delirium tremens: Delirium tremens (DT) is an acute and severe form of alcohol withdrawal. It typically presents with symptoms such as tremors, confusion, hallucinations, delirium, and autonomic instability (e.g., elevated heart rate, blood pressure). However, the neurological symptoms such as ataxia, CN6 involvement, and nystagmus are more consistent with Wernicke's encephalopathy rather than DT.
  • D.Declerembault syndrome: This is not a well-recognized or commonly diagnosed condition in clinical practice. It may refer to a variant of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) or be a misspelling of Paris syndrome, a psychological disorder that can occur in some individuals when they visit Paris, but it does not relate to alcohol use or neurological symptoms like ataxia or cranial nerve involvement.

Key Takeaways:

  • Wernicke's encephalopathy is an acute neurological condition caused by thiamine deficiency often seen in chronic alcoholics, presenting with ataxia, cranial nerve VI involvement, and nystagmus.
  • Immediate thiamine replacement is critical in preventing progression to Korsakoff syndrome, which involves chronic memory issues.

questions.text: A male patient comes with history of marital conflicts and complains of early ejaculation. Which of the following non pharmacological method may be useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
The squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological approach used to treat premature ejaculation. It involves the partner squeezing the tip or base of the penis just before ejaculation to interrupt the process. This action helps reduce arousal and delay ejaculation. The technique is repeated during subsequent sexual activities to help train the body's response and improve ejaculatory control.

Other options:

  • B.CBT (Cognitive Behavioural Therapy): While CBT can be helpful in various sexual and psychological disorders, it is not specifically indicated for the treatment of premature ejaculation. CBT focuses on identifying and modifying thought patterns and behaviours that contribute to psychological distress and dysfunction.
  • C.Exposure and response prevention: This therapeutic approach is commonly used in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and related conditions. It involves exposing the patient to anxiety-provoking situations while preventing the usual compulsive response. It is not a standard treatment for premature ejaculation.
  • D. Sensate focus technique: The sensate focus technique is a type of sex therapy that involves a series of behavioural exercises to enhance the couple's intimacy and reduce performance anxiety. While it can be beneficial for improving overall sexual satisfaction, it is not a specific treatment for premature ejaculation.

Key Takeaways:

  • The squeeze technique is a well-established non-pharmacological method to treat premature ejaculation, helping to delay ejaculation and improve control over time.
  • While other methods like CBT and sensate focus can be beneficial for broader emotional and sexual health, they are not specifically targeted for treating premature ejaculation.

questions.text: Which of the following is included in formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Formal Thought Disorder: Disturbances in structure and organization of thinking. Most commonly seen in schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders.

This is an example of formal thought disorder. It occurs when a person's thoughts move from one topic to another without a clear or logical connection. This can make their speech disorganized and difficult to follow. In the example provided, the individual starts with a thought about going to Bangalore but then abruptly shifts to a completely unrelated topic, such as Ramesh being smart. Derailment is common in schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders, where the structure of thought is impaired.

Examples for common formal thought disorder:

ØLoosening of Association: There is no association between two different thoughts or ideas.

  • Q- What is your name?
  • A-I am peon in no one's life become easy.

ØDerailment- one thought slides into another.

  • I am going to Bangalore. Ramesh is very smart

ØOmission- senseless omission of a thought or part of it

  • This person Mr...... told me that ...sleep

ØFusion- heterogenous elements of thought are interwoven together

  • I am going to very smart

ØDrivelling- disordered intermixture of constituent parts of one complex thought

  • He shot a bullet. Tiger jumped on him. He went to forest. He shocked.

ØSubstitution- major thought is substituted by a subsidiary one

  • Q - which festival will you celebrate?
  • A - We will celebrate... at my sister's place

Incorrect Options Explanations:

  • B.Obsession: Obsessions are intrusive and repetitive thoughts, urges, or images that cause anxiety or distress. They are characteristic of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), not formal thought disorders. Obsessions are more related to the content of thought, not the organization or structure of it.
  • C.Thought insertion: Thought insertion is a positive symptom of schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders. It refers to the belief that one's thoughts are being placed into their mind by an external force, which is a delusion. While it involves abnormal thinking, it is not a formal thought disorder. It pertains more to the content of the thoughts rather than the structure or organization.
  • D. Delusion: Delusions are false beliefs that are held with strong conviction despite evidence to the contrary. These can include beliefs such as thinking one has special powers or is being persecuted. Delusions represent a disturbance in the content of thought, not the formal structure of thinking. While delusions are often seen in psychosis, they are not classified as formal thought disorders.

Key Takeaways:

  • Formal thought disorders involve disruptions in the structure and organization of thought, as seen in conditions like schizophrenia. Derailment is a classic example of this, where thoughts move from one topic to another without a logical connection.
  • Other symptoms like obsessions and delusions relate more to the content of thought, not its organization.

questions.text: During the course of psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards the patient, this is known as:
questions.solution:
Countertransferenceis a phenomenon in psychotherapy where thetherapistunconsciouslyprojects their emotions, feelings or past experiencesonto the patient. It occurs when the therapist has unresolved issues or emotional reactions triggered by the patient's behaviour, appearance or history. Countertransference can influence the therapeutic relationship and the therapist's ability to be objective and provide effective treatment.

Other Options:

A.Transference- Transference is the patient's unconscious redirection of feelings and desires from significant people in their life onto the therapist. It is a normal and expected process in psychotherapy.

C. Dissociation- Dissociation refers to a disconnection between thoughts, identity, consciousness and memory. It is not directly related to the therapist-patient relationship in psychotherapy.

D. Preoccupation- Preoccupation generally refers to being excessively concerned or focused on something. While it is a psychological term, it is not specifically related to the therapist's feelings towards the patient during psychotherapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Countertransference is when the therapist unconsciously projects their emotions or past experiences onto the patient, which can affect the therapeutic process.
  • Transference is the reverse, where the patient redirects their feelings or experiences onto the therapist.

questions.text: A man sits naked on his balcony every evening when there are many people in the garden. Which type of paraphilia is this?
questions.solution:
Exhibitionism is a type of paraphilia in which an individual gains sexual excitement from exposing their genitals to others, often in public settings or situations where it is inappropriate. In this case, the man sitting naked on his balcony where there are many people in the garden is an example of exhibitionism. The behavior involves exposing oneself to others without their consent, which is the central feature of this disorder.

Incorrect Options:

  • A. Sadism: Sadism refers to gaining sexual pleasure from inflicting pain, suffering, or humiliation on another person. The scenario does not involve the infliction of pain or suffering but rather the act of exposure for arousal, so it is not sadism.
  • B.Frotteurism: Frotteurism involves touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person for sexual pleasure. It typically happens in crowded settings, like public transport, where the person may secretly rub against others. This is different from exhibitionism, as it involves physical contact rather than exposure.
  • D. Scoptophilia: Scoptophilia refers to gaining sexual arousal from watching others without their knowledge, often associated with voyeurism. While this could involve a situation where someone is watching others, the behavior in the scenario is about exposing oneself to others, which fits exhibitionism, not scoptophilia.

Key Takeaway:

Exhibitionism involves exposing one's body, often in inappropriate settings, to others for sexual arousal.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol for 3 days(72 hrs) and presented with irritability disorientation, paranoid delusion, visual hallucinations and altered sensorium. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described in the scenario, such asirritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations and altered sensorium,are characteristic of delirium tremens. Delirium tremens (DT) is asevere form of alcohol withdrawalthat typically occurs in individuals with a history of heavy and prolonged alcohol use. It usuallydevelops within 2 to 4 days after stopping alcoholconsumption and is considered a medical emergency due to its potentially life-threatening complications.

Other Options:

A. Alcohol withdrawal seizure-Alcohol withdrawal seizures are seizures that can occur in individualswho abruptly stop or reduce their alcohol intake. While seizures can be part of alcohol withdrawal, the other symptoms described in the scenario are more indicative of delirium tremens.

B.Wernicke's encephalopathy-Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological disorder caused bythiamine(vitamin B1) deficiency,often associated with alcohol use disorder. It can present with a triad of symptoms, includingconfusion, ataxia (lack of coordination) and eye movement abnormalities. However, the symptoms described in the scenario go beyond the typical triad and are more consistent with delirium tremens.

D. Korsakoff's psychosis-Korsakoff's psychosis is achronic memory disordercaused by thiamine deficiency and oftenoccurs as a result of Wernicke's encephalopathy. While it can cause memory deficits, it is not associated with the acute and severe symptoms described in the scenario. Delirium tremens is a more likely diagnosis given the acute presentation of symptoms after alcohol cessation

Key Takeaway:

Delirium tremens (DT) is the correct diagnosis, presenting with delirium, hallucinations, and disorientation in a patient who has stopped alcohol after heavy, prolonged use. It typically occurs 2-4 days after alcohol cessation and is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent medical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in cocaine intoxication?
questions.solution:
Cocaine intoxication is known to stimulate the central nervous system and cause various physiological effects. The symptoms typically seen during cocaine intoxication include:

  • Hyperthermia: Cocaine use can increase body temperature due to its stimulant effects on the central nervous system.
  • Agitation: Cocaine is a stimulant, which can lead to agitation, restlessness, and hyperactivity.
  • Myocardial infarction: Cocaine use can cause vasoconstriction, which increases the risk of myocardial infarction (heart attack), especially in individuals with preexisting cardiovascular disease.

Why Bradycardia is Incorrect:

  • Bradycardia (slow heart rate) is not typically seen in cocaine intoxication. Instead, tachycardia (rapid heart rate) is common. Cocaine stimulates the sympathetic nervous system, leading to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cocaine intoxication often leads to tachycardia, agitation, hyperthermia, and myocardial infarction due to its stimulant effects.
  • Bradycardia is not typically a feature of cocaine intoxication; instead, it is associated with conditions like opioid toxicity or vagal stimulation.
